text: okay all right hi everyone nothing face
tano here the internet's busiest music
nerd and it's time for a review of this
new salt album nine this is the latest
full-length lp from the anonymous london
music collective known as salt they've
been having a kind of prolific run over
the past few years and beautifully in
the midst of it all they've been able to
maintain this sort of shadowy
presentation which is especially
impressive in the social media age if
you have no earthly idea what i'm
talking about go back and listen to
their 2020 output untitled rise untitled
black is records that are not only
packed with tracks that are in direct
response to the uprisings of last year
but also stark and creative production
that brings together elements of hip-hop
jazz
soul psych funk post punk and more sadly
they were records that i was slow to hop
on to and not covering them was
unfortunately one of my biggest regrets
of last year now of course i couldn't
miss another opportunity to talk about
the group's music especially in light of
being filled in on them a little bit in
a recent conversation with uk rapper
little sims who appears on this lp now
she didn't spill too much information
about the size of the group who's in the
group or anything like that but
she did sort of imply this revolving
door of collaborators and also that i
wouldn't believe some of the people that
are in the group and honestly i wouldn't
be surprised if there were some really
notable musicians in salt's midst the
production is so creative the
musicianship is good and the creative
direction is on another level and nine
over here comes attached to a kind of
interesting concept as well as this
project was released with the
understanding that it would only be
available for 99 days so yeah streaming
downloads all that as soon as 99 days
are up this thing is gone but still
going through the process of recording
releasing and then taking away this
record does certainly say something
about the permanence of media in the
digital age now with that being said
comparatively to their previous releases
9 is not one of the more robust salt
projects that's for sure i think overall
it does kind of pale in comparison to
their 2020 records but there are still
some highlights london gangs stuck out
as one of my favorites here i loved the
jazzy drum breaks the distorted bass
loops the trip hop influence on this one
is huge the vocals and much of
everything else are soaked in this eerie
atmosphere that's sort of been a
trademark of salt sound up until this
point there's something kind of haunting
about all of it meanwhile the lyrics are
reflecting on
gang culture cycles of violence and
destitution i also love the folk melody
that the bass and vocals lock into
between the verses
there's also the track trap life which
has these fantastic drum circle rhythms
some cute cartoonish group vocals as
well which i think is one of the unique
draws for nine in salt's discography so
far the cheeky refrains the group vocals
are singing are
so funny but yet also acknowledging some
really grim realities like the imagery
is really gritty but simultaneously
there is a childlike innocence to the la
la la la
the whole track eventually breaking into
this noisy cross-cultural beat switch
featuring some shouty mia type wrap
flows on top of it then alcohol is a
change of pace in that it is a very
downtrodden neo-soul ballad with a great
vocal performance just a devastating
addiction durge the title track is a
kind of whimsical psychedelic ballad as
well that i like quite a bit but my
issue with some of these songs
ultimately and i guess the record on the
whole is that
here and there while there are some
great ideas brought to the table there's
just not enough meat on the bones
they're not built on as thoroughly as
they could be the track fear i think is
an example of this the steady groove on
this track is fine the building layers
of buzzing bass and vocal chants some
spoken word as well reflecting on pain
but the way the whole thing progresses
it kind of builds and builds and builds
without much of a payoff eventually just
dropping out bitter streets had some
great ideas but kind of a
one-dimensional structure as well and
you from london was the track i was
referring to earlier with little sims on
it i like the concept of the track it
contributes to this record sense of
place and also is one of the funnier
moments here i also appreciate the fact
that while little sims is featured on
the record her voice is manipulated in a
way where it seems like she's coming
like out of that salt universe but with
that being said i do think this track
features one of the more half-baked
beats and i think another verse really
would have brought things home lights in
your hands i thought was a fitting
closer for the lp it's a powerful track
with some gospel inspiration a strong
lead vocal eventually transitioning into
this spoken word passage talking about
uh just dealing every day with
fear anxiety what that does to your
mentality as a kid eventually
transitioning into an adult while i
think the track does lose some momentum
in this change it does gain a lot of
meaning not just for itself but for the
record as a whole yeah overall i think
this record really just kind of boils
down to being left
wanting more at the end of the day it's
pretty good and continues to advance
salt's unique sound but i also think
they've come out with better and have my
fingers crossed that we'll be hearing
more from them sooner rather than later
i'm feeling a strong six to a light
seven on this one tran position have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best of the best what
should i review next hit like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video that you
can check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
music salt
forever
